repnme.cdata!: Access to technical education in India

abstracts.cdata!:
Liberalization of the Indian economy,
            its gradual integration with the world economy, and rapid
            transformation into a knowledge-based society are increasing
            the demand for a well-trained workforce that is not only
            literate and has mastered specific skills, but is also able
            to acquire new skills and knowledge independently. To meet
            the demands of the changing labor market, International
            Development Association (IDA) supported India's long
            term program of reforms in the middle level technical
            education system dealing with training of technicians and
            supervisors. There was increase in the number of
            well-trained technicians in India and in women's access
            to both technical education and good jobs. For example: some
            25,000 technicians per year since 1998 trained in over 200
            new and high technology areas. A new long term program of
            major institutional reforms at degree level institutions for
            engineering education has begun.

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is highly
            satisfactory, ensuring a highly likely sustainability. The
            project achieved its objectives, which were clearly defined,
            and relevant to national policies, most importantly, it laid
            the foundation for greater self-reliance of polytechnics,
            and for partnerships with industry, and community, in the
            management, and financing of polytechnics. Among the many
            lessons learned, the project re-enforced the importance of
            full ownership, and commitments of the States, in tandem
            with Government policy support, since the effective central
            coordination promoted competition, facilitated a responsive
            management, and further enhanced industrial participation in
            manpower development. But regardless of a proven effective
            decentralization, special attention by the Bank, should be
            given to local implementing agencies, particularly in
            providing technical assistance at the early stages of the
            project. It is important to record, and maintain a system
            for a timely flow of funds, and disbursements, to
            systematically release funds, such as a line allocation to
            the project account, which could have reduced the delays
            faced in civil works, and procurement. The intense
            field-based supervision allowed a close interaction with the
            Borrower, and beneficiaries, which proved to be not only
            effective, but economical as well.

18155813.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Education for the knowledge economy,Education for all,Gender,Technology diffusion
18155813.majtheme: Rural development,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Trade and integration

abstracts.cdata!:
The goal of this project is to support
            the national policy on education. The main objectives
            include: capacity expansion which would be achieved by
            expanding and diversifying programs in about 240 new and
            existing institutions, so that they can undertake with
            flexibility, courses in new and emerging technologies,
            conventional and advanced technician engineering, and
            continuing education diploma courses.  Special attention
            will also be given to expanding and improving training
            opportunities for women, rural populations and the informal
            sector by establishing new women's residential
            polytechnics, upgrading coeducational polytechnics to create
            more opportunities for women, and expanding the number of
            community polytechnics.  Quality improvement will be
            achieved through modernizing the equipment and facilities of
            polytechnics, expanding and improving the quality of
            training of polytechnic teachers and undertaking curriculum
            development activities.  Efficiency improvement will result
            from strengthening state directorates and boards of
            technical education, granting academic autonomy to selected
            polytechnics, undertaking industry-institute interaction
            programs in each polytechnic, encouraging internal revenue
            generation in polytechnics and establishing equipment and
            facility maintenance systems.
